etymologies: Middle English: from re- and flux

definitions: the flow of a fluid through a vessel or valve in the body in a direction opposite to normal

examples.text: the majority of leg ulcer patients are elderly with simple superficial vein reflux
the main culprit is bile reflux, a backup of digestive fluid that is supposed to remain in the small intestine.

shortDefinitions: flow of body fluid in direction opposite to normal

definitions: a condition in which acidic gastric fluid overflows into the esophagus, resulting in heartburn

examples.text: knowing which foods cause reflux is crucial in alleviating symptoms

shortDefinitions: condition in which gastric fluid overflows into oesophagus

definitions: (in a baby after feeding) the regurgitation of the contents of the stomach into the mouth

examples.text: babies are prone to reflux because they have tiny stomachs

shortDefinitions: regurgitation of contents of stomach into mouth

definitions: the process of boiling a liquid so that any vapor is liquefied and returned to the stock

examples.text: the mixture was heated at reflux under nitrogen

shortDefinitions: process of boiling liquid so that any vapour is liquefied and returned to stock

definitions: (of a fluid) flow backwards through a vessel or valve in the body

examples.text: acidic secretions of the stomach can reflux back upwards

notes.text: no object, with adverbial of direction

definitions: boil or cause to boil in circumstances such that the vapor returns to the stock of liquid after condensing

examples.text: the liquid is allowed to reflux until the thermometer records the lowest temperature possible
the solutions were refluxed for 9–12 hours

shortDefinitions: boil so that vapour returns to stock of liquid after condensing
